Graphical abstract Selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 over zeolite catalysts is recognized as the most practical technology used in mobile exhaust gases to transform NOx into N2. Despite a comprehensive structural-activity insight into Cu-zeolite SCR catalyst, Fe-zeolite, which is also popular in the automotive catalysis community, is necessary to be thoroughly investigated on micro-mechanism. This review summarizes the highlights and challenges in the application of Fe-zeolite, and simultaneously analyzes the reasons of some peculiar properties, such as the NH3 inhibition effect at low temperatures, the low N2O production and the sensitivity to NO2/NOx ratio in the feed. In addition, some feasible strategies are classified and summarized subsequently to provide suggestions for the improvement of low-temperature activity, the enhancement of resistance to hydrothermal aging and sulfur poisoning, the construction of controlled structure and the combination of Fe- and Cu- zeolites. Finally, the reaction mechanisms of NH3-SCR over Fe-zeolites are concluded. After establishing a comprehensive overview of Fe-zeolite SCR catalysts, some directions that remain to be thoroughly explored on Fe-zeolite are put forward to assist the future catalyst design and investigation of NH3-SCR. Keywords Fe-zeolite NH3-SCR High-temperature activity NH3inhibition N2O Deactivation 1 Introduction 1.1 The application of metal-exchanged zeolite catalysts for NOx elimination in mobile field Environmental harmful compounds, such as unburnt hydrocarbons, oxides of sulfur, particulate matter and carbon oxide, are the target components to be removed from automotive exhaust gas. Among them, NOx emissions from the combustion of fuels have long been considered to be deleterious atmospheric pollutant, which causes an adverse effect on both the environment and human health [1]. Considerable research interests on heterogeneous catalytic technologies have been focused on the catalytic removal of NOx. The selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 (NH3-SCR) is a commercially available NOx abatement technology that reduces the NOx to N2 since the 1970s [2]. Many endeavors have been made to reduce air pollution from transportation by means of modifying the combustion system and upgrading the aftertreatment technology [3]. Nowadays, the utilization of compression ignition engine based on diesel/biodiesel fuels blends is carried out to boost high thermal efficiency and to achieve the sustainable use of energy [4]. Because of the variation of combustion system to lean-burn condition, the noble-metal based three-way catalysts used in car emissions (gasoline engines) and vanadia-based catalysts applied in stationary source are no longer applicable to diesel engine. Although the lean combustion environment is a very attractive solution to diminish consumption and CO2 emission, it poses great challenges to NOx elimination in oxygen-rich conditions, which is a daunting task [5]. Catalyst plays a decisive role in SCR technology, making the need to modify existing catalysts or develop novel materials urgent. On the one hand, the real conditions for diesel engine are far from being constant, leading to the demand for stable and high-efficiency catalysts in aftertreatment system. A wide active temperature window between 150 and 650℃ as well as the exclusive selectivity to N2 are needed. In addition, high stability is desired to overcome the harsh steam environment [6]. On the other hand, with increasingly stringent emission norms introduced, typically for the Euro 6 standard regulation in 2014, the NOx emission limit is set to 0.08 g/km, which is 55.6 % less than the Euro 5 in 2009 [7]. As such, the above factors necessitate the development of harmless zeolites as alternative catalysts in SCR. 1.2 The development of Fe-zeolite SCR catalysts Metal-exchanged zeolites outperform vanadia-based catalysts in both SCR activity across a wide temperature range and thermal stability [8]. In view of vehicle accelerations operating and occasional high temperature events (soot combustion and desulfation), considerable investigations are needed for Fe-zeolite catalysts with superiority in high-temperature performance. In the early 1990s, ZSM-5 loaded Cu or Fe as SCR catalysts with hydrocarbon or NH3 as reductants received much attention on account of the comparable or even better performance than the commercialized V2O5/WO3-TiO2 [9,10]. At temperatures typical of diesel exhaust, Fe-ZSM-5 showed higher hydrothermal stability than Cu-ZSM-5 [11–14]. Nonetheless, the inferior low-temperature activity of Fe-ZSM-5 hampered its further applications [15]. Consequently, beta zeolite involving Cu or Fe became the major research objective because of their enhanced durability [16,17]. Iron containing catalysts based on ZSM-5 and beta zeolites were compared by He et al. [18] with respect to activity, hydrothermal stability and hydrocarbon coking resistance. It was found that Fe/Beta-zeolite performed better in every respect. However, whether it is ZSM-5 with medium pores or beta with large pores, there is a common problem that hydrocarbon can easily poison the zeolite by strong adsorption. Furthermore, the greatly exothermic combustion of hydrocarbons may degrade the zeolite topology. Moreover, the lack of breakthrough in improving the hydrothermal stability drives further exploration towards small-pore zeolites. Chabazite (CHA) zeolites with small pores were expected to be less susceptible to deactivation by poisoning and aging due to the specific properties from small opening. Cu-exchanged CHA zeolites (SAPO-34 and SSZ-13) were developed and commercially applied for lean-NOx NH3-SCR in diesel vehicles in around 2010 [19,20]. After several years, Fe/SSZ-13 with excellent high-temperature activity was reported by Gao et al. [21]. Our unpublished works on Fe-SSZ-13 have dealt with the evolution of Fe species with calcination temperature and the improvement of hydrothermal stability by Zr doping, respectively. Subsequently, Fe-SAPO-34 was also prepared, showing outstanding high-temperature deNOx activity and high resistance towards hydrothermal treatment [22,23]. Besides, alternative zeolite, for instance Fe-exchanged high-silica LTA, was developed and demonstrated to possess superior hydrothermal stability than Fe-SSZ-13 in NH3-SCR [24]. With the aim to perfect the SCR performance and lifetime, novel catalysts will always be the subject of academic community. 1.3 The scope and objective of this review In the last few decades, a wide number of reviews have covered subjects about previous achievements in NH3-SCR. Recent advances in NOx emission control on Cu-zeolite catalysts were summarized by Beale et al. [25] and Wang et al. [26], giving a comprehensive microstructure insight and far-reaching application prospect. It should be noted that Fe-zeolite is considered for commercial application because of its advantage in the fast-SCR reaction. Moreover, Fe-zeolite was shown to achieve higher NOx conversion under real-world transient condition. Thereby, the intention of this paper is to review the characteristic properties of Fe-zeolite in comparison to Cu-zeolite for SCR reaction. Specifically, its highlights of excellent high-temperature activity, low N2O selectivity, sensitivity to NO2 and resistant to chemical poisoning as well as its drawbacks of inconvenience in preparation, low-temperature NH3 inhibition effect and hydrothermal deactivation are listed and analyzed. Also, the solutions to optimize the performance of Fe-zeolite catalysts in different aspects are systematically summarized. Finally, the reaction mechanisms of NH3-SCR over Fe-zeolites are discussed. These characteristics are directly related to the on-road application of iron-based catalysts, which guide the direction of physical and chemical modification. 2 Opportunities and highlights of Fe-zeolite for NH3-SCR application The chemistry of Fe-zeolite in NH3-SCR is different from that of Cu-zeolite in some ways. The strong oxophilicity of iron creates distinctive interaction with zeolite framework and hydroxyl groups. Therefore, the coordination of Fe is closely related to the catalyst composition and reaction condition. Moreover, the charge property of Fen+ counterion and the redox of Fe2+/Fe3+ ion pair differ from that of Cun+ and Cu+/Cu2+. Furthermore, there is a difference between Cu- and Fe-zeolite in the nature and strength of complexes forming with NH3/NOx. Fe-zeolite combines more weakly with NH3 with comparison to Cu-zeolite. These features in return affect the reaction rate of NH3-SCR. Accordingly, several advantages of Fe-zeolites that overshadow Cu-zeolites are outlined here. 2.1 Excellent catalytic performance at high temperatures In previous studies, Fe-zeolites containing extraframework iron species have been identified as highly active catalysts for many reactions, including selective oxidation of benzene and methane, selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 or hydrocarbon and N2O decomposition [27]. In the application of NH3-SCR reaction, the most brilliant feature is that Fe-zeolite catalysts show higher NOx conversion at medium-high temperatures than Cu-zeolite. While the optimal range of Cu-zeolite catalysts is in low temperatures range. Above 400℃, the undesired NH3 oxidation rate over Cu-zeolite increases quickly, resulting in the decline of SCR efficiency [28]. Conversely, a slower NH3 oxidation rate is observed on Fe-zeolites. Grossale et al. comparatively investigated the reactivity of the NO/NH3-O2 SCR reaction by dynamic methods over commercial zeolite catalysts promoted with Fe and Cu. It was found that Cu-zeolite was more active at 200℃ (as high as 35 %) than Fe-zeolite (less than 10 %) [29]. Kamasamudram et al. explicated the behavior difference between Fe- and Cu-zeolite from the aspect of mechanism [30]. It was found that Cu-zeolite showed superior steady-state low-temperature performance under standard/fast SCR reaction atmosphere. Its NO conversion gradually decreased with increasing temperature. While Fe-zeolite showed higher activity at higher temperature regardless of the NO2/NOx. In another study, Metkar and coworkers tested standard SCR activity on both Fe-ZSM-5 and Cu-CHA [31]. It is confirmed that Cu-CHA achieved nearly 100 % NO conversion in temperature window of 250−350℃. Subsequently, the NO conversion decreased with temperature increasing, which was due to the ammonia oxidation side reaction. For Fe-ZSM-5, its activity was preferable only at temperature above 400℃. To sum up, Fe-zeolite catalysts are more suitable for heavy duty diesel engines, in which the temperature of exhaust gas is relatively higher in comparation to the light duty diesel engines. 2.2 Low selectivity to N2O N2O, also known as laughing gas, is one of the by-product of NH3-SCR reaction. As the application of NOx catalytic convert technology in vehicle, the rapid development of transportation becomes a significant source of N2O. Though the N2O content only levels up to tens of ppm in SCR system, more and more attention is drawn to its elimination. The harmful impact of N2O on greenhouse effect is rather embarrassed since its harm is 310 and 21 times higher than CO2 and CH4, respectively [32]. Also, N2O can chemically convert in the stratosphere to form NO, contributing to ozone layer depletion. Among a number of research, Fe-zeolites are not only used for the NH3-SCR of NOx but also for N2O decomposition and reduction [33]. They are insensitive to other exhaust compound (O2, H2O, NO and SO2) coexisting in a typical SCR surrounding [34]. N2O forms during NH3-SCR reaction catalyzed by Cu-zeolite regardless of the presence of NO2 [35]. Further, N2O concentration increases with increasing NO2/NOx ratio [36,37]. In contrast, Fe-zeolite produces negligible amount of N2O in standard SCR reaction. In condition that NO2 is added to the feed or that the catalyst is treated by hydrothermal aging, N2O production over Fe-zeolite increases and becomes observable [38–40]. The typical image of N2O concentration variation with NO2/NOx ratio and temperature is depicted in Fig. 1 . Several probable reactions were considerable to explain N2O formation: 1) The selective catalytic oxidation of NH3 by O2 or NO2 at high temperatures. In the SCR process, O2 and NO2 are expected oxidant. NO2 even shows stronger oxidability than O2 at temperature below 350℃: (1) 4 N H 3 + 4 O 2 → 2 N 2 O + 6 H 2 O (2) 6 N H 3 + 8 N O 2 → 7 N 2 O + 9 H 2 O (3) 4 N H 3 + 4 N O 2 + O 2 → 4 N 2 O + 6 H 2 O 2) N2O formation via decomposition of deposited NH4NO3 at low temperatures. Especially for low-temperature fast SCR, the surface adsorbed NH3 and NO2 interact mutually, leading to NH4NO3 deposition. Thus NH4NO3 inhibits NO conversion below its decomposition temperature (∼200℃) by blocking the zeolite pores and covering the active sites: (4) 2 N H 3 + 2 N O 2 → N 2 + N H 4 N O 3 + H 2 O (5) N H 4 N O 3 → N 2 O + 2 H 2 O For comparison purpose, the scenarios where N2O formation is promoted over Fe- and Cu-zeolite are displayed in Fig. 2 [28]. The situation where the NO2/NOx ratio is lower than 0.5 is closer to the practical NO2/NOx ratio in exhaust. It is obvious that the N2O outlet concentration for SCR over Cu-zeolite increases as the NO2/NOx ratio varying from 0 to 0.5. Differently, nearly no N2O forms for SCR over Fe-zeolite when the NO2/NOx ratio increases from 0 to 0.5. However, much more N2O is detected in NO2-SCR reaction when the NO2/NOx ratio is higher than 0.5. The advantage of poor N2O selectivity (high N2 selectivity) over Fe-zeolite was also seen in ref. [39], where Fe-beta and Fe-ZSM-5 zeolites presented only the maximum N2O selectivity of 3%, a lower value than N2O output of Cu-containing zeolites in the presence and absence of NO2. This was again confirmed by the temperature-programmed desorption results after SCR reactions [21,38]. The concentrations of H2O, N2O, NH3 and NO2 were measured to evaluate NH4NO3 deposition. It is proposed that the decomposition of NH4NO3 is the low-temperature N2O source. Overall, the benefit of low N2O selectivity for Fe-zeolite may result from the following N2O decomposition and N2O-SCR pathway: (6) 2 N 2 O → 2 N 2 + O 2 (7) 3 N 2 O + 2 N H 3 → 4 N 2 + 3 H 2 O In light of this, Fe-zeolite can be used as co-catalyst to consume N2O generated by Cu-zeolite. This was demonstrated to be achievable in ref. [38]. 2.3 Sensitivity to NO2/NOx ratio On account of the installation of diesel oxidation catalysts (DOC) upstream of the SCR system, the presence of NO2 is inevitable in diesel exhaust. Even so, NO is still the component with the highest content in NOx that makes up about 90 %. Objectively, the effect of NO2/NOx ratio in a wide range from 0 to 1 is of vital importance to be considered as confirmed in ref. [41]. It is well known that Cu-zeolite is insensitive to NO2/NOx ratio in feed. As for Fe-zeolite, a feasible approach to enhance the low-temperature SCR activity is to increase the NO2/NOx ratio, so that facilitating the fast-SCR reaction [42]. The promotion effect is intuitively seen in Fig. 3 . As also suggested by Metkar et al. [31], both the experimental study and the global kinetic modeling presented the same relations concerning the N2 yield versus the NO2/NOx ratio and temperature. The results in Fig. 4 (a) show that the maximum selective conversion of NOx to N2 was obtained at NO2/NOx = 0.5 over Fe-ZSM-5. Specially for temperature below 300℃, the slope of N2 concentration curve is dramatic with the increase of NO2/NOx ratio. This indicates a rapid elevation of low-temperature SCR reaction rate by introducing NO2. Nevertheless, the N2 selectivity declines sharply when the NO2/NOx ratio > 0.5. In the case of Cu-CHA shown in Fig. 4 (b), the low-temperature activity is excellent and no significant promotion by NO2 is observed in the whole temperature region. Slight decline of N2 production is found, which may be explained by the formation of NH4NO3 when NO2 react with NH3 [37]. It can be seen from the above that regulating the NO/NO2 outlet ratio at DOC is important to achieve efficient NOx conversion in SCR unit. Catalyst in DOC mostly contains Pt as active component, which combines with a support with high surface area [43]. It can catalyze oxidation NO to NO2. Further, the NO oxidation rate may depend on the exhaust gas temperature and composition, the catalyst formula, the catalyst treatment, as well as the chemical valence states and the dispersion of Pt active species. To improve the NO2 production, some works can be referred. Auvray et al. investigated the effect of gas composition during thermal aging of 1 wt.% Pt/Al2O3 [44]. It pointed out that the reaction was structure sensitive and the decrease of platinum dispersion led to the increase the NO oxidation activity. Specifically, the SO2 + O2 atmosphere shows the ability to promote platinum sintering and NO oxidation conversion changed from 45 % to 76 %. Ding et al. prepared a Ce-modified Pt/15CeSA catalyst by impregnation method, which showed 62 % NO maximum conversion to NO2 [45]. And the main contribution to the remarkable catalytic activity was explained by the improved Pt particles distribution and oxygen vacancies induced by the PtOCeOAl interface. It is worth noting that the increase of NO2 not only facilitates the low-temperature NH3-SCR activity but also promotes the soot oxidation in DPF. Overall, although the sensitivity of Fe-zeolite to NO2 is benefit for itself, which creates opportunity to improve low-temperature activity. In a practical way, owning to the substantial changes of gas flow and temperature, it is difficult to control a consistent NO2 fraction via the peroxidation catalyst, which may not provide stable purification efficiency. Hence, accurate NO2 concentration regulation is required for making the utmost use of its sensitivity to NO2. The question about what mechanism is responsible for the positive effect of NO2 introduction remains a subject to be solved. Some authors believe that NO oxidation to NO2 is the rate limiting step for standard SCR [46]. Thus the presence of NO2 in the feed can step over the necessary NO oxidation step and accelerate the reaction process. The inference was confirmed by the experimental findings that strong promoting effect happened when NO2 was included in standard SCR both on H-type or metal-exchanged zeolite [47]. However, the perspective of NO2 formation as rate limiting step has been questioned in several ways [48]. First, NO oxidation reaction is much slower than standard SCR reaction [49,50]. Second, the influence of water is different to standard, fast SCR and NO oxidation reactions [51,52]. These make it unreasonable to draw a conclusion on the rate-limiting role of NO oxidation. In fact, the contribution of standard, fast and NO2 SCR reactions over Fe-zeolite was discussed by Iwasaki et al. [53]. A common reaction mechanism plotted in Fig. 5 was elucidated to be contained in different SCR reaction. Namely, NO2 adsorbs at catalyst surface and then disproportionate to nitrate/nitrite intermediate. Nitrate is further reduced by NO to form N2, which is the rate-determining step for fast-SCR [54]. Based on this, it's almost certain that the introduction of NO2 can skip over NO activation step and easily contribute to NO2-adsorbed species formation. However, NH4NO3 inhibition for fast SCR at low temperature may slower the NO conversion rate in comparison to standard SCR. Besides, N2O formation discussed in Section 2.2 is from NH4NO3 decomposition when NO2 is excess. It has to be emphasized that the precise pathway in which high valency N-containing intermediate forms is still not fully understood. 2.4 Good resistance to sulfur poisoning Under the real operation of diesel engines, chemical poisoning, hydrothermal deactivation and hydrocarbon poisoning are three dominating inactivation patterns. Hydrocarbon poisoning and coking occur preferentially on zeolite strong acid sites when the DOC system failures. The durability towards hydrocarbon poisoning mainly depends on the pore size of zeolites, wherein the small pore structure restrains the diffusion. Also, hydrothermal deactivation is greatly influenced by zeolite structure. These properties are common to Cu- and Fe-zeolites with various topology. However, chemical poisoning of zeolite by inorganic impurities is strongly linked to the toxicants-metal interaction and the chemisorption of active sites. In this respect, Fe-zeolite shows some superior properties owning to the discrepancy between Fe and Cu. As is clear from the previous descriptions, the metal containing zeolite catalysts surpass the vanadia-based catalysts in many ways. But when it comes to the tolerance towards SO2, zeolite catalysts perform not as well as vanadia-based catalysts [55]. The impact of sulfur poisoning is prominent below 300℃. Among the zeolite catalysts, however, it is commonly known that Fe-zeolite is more resistant to sulfur than Cu-zeolite catalyst [56–58]. As shown in Fig. 6 , Fe-ZSM-5 maintained its catalytic performance at 400−550℃ despite the aging treatment in 500 ppm SO2 and 10 % H2O. And the effect of SO2 was almost negligible when compared to the activity after pretreatment in 10 % H2O at 700℃ for 24 h only [56]. Another study by Silver et al. investigated the effect of phosphorus on Fe-zeolite SCR catalyst in the absence/presence of sulfur [59]. It was proposed that moderate amounts of S (350 ppm) did not significantly deactivate this formulation. Apart from sulfur, the deactivation effects of other inorganics are parallel issues to be considered. These contaminants include Ca, Mg, Zn, P, B, Mo, K, Na, Cl etc., which come from lubricant oil addictive, impurities in diesel fuel, urea solution and aerosol particulate from intake air. Few studies in open literature have discussed the chemical deactivation of Fe-zeolites used as NH3-SCR catalysts [60]. A typical study by P. Kern et al. via high-throughput experiments has evaluated the poisoning extent of various inorganic matters to Fe-zeolites [61,62]. The effects on the catalytic properties of Fe-zeolite by inorganics can be divided into three types: 1) Additives with promoting effect (Cu(NO3)2, (NH4)2CrO4, Fe(NO3)3); 2) Additives with deactivating effect (alkaline- and earth alkaline-metals; zinc, phosphates and borates); 3) Additives without significant influence (aluminium, cerium, chlorides). It was noted that Fe-zeolites instead of vanadia-based materials are to be recommended due to the far less adverse impact of alkaline metals to the former one. In conclusion, the resistance to chemical poisoning is indispensable in practical application. More attention should be focused in this regard to obtain useful guidance in the design of Fe-zeolites catalysts, especially to detail deactivation mechanisms. 2.5 Summary In this part, the advantages of Fe-zeolite as NH3-SCR catalyst over Cu-zeolite is discussed separately, i.e. the excellent catalytic performance at high temperatures, the low selectivity to N2O, the sensitivity to NO2/NOx ratio and the good resistance to sulfur poisoning. These features offer the opportunities for the application of Fe-zeolite in real condition. Beside, some disadvantages of Fe-zeolite should also be considered. These will be discussed in detail below. 3 The challenges of Fe-zeolite in the application of NH3-SCR reaction Given that performance defects offer the breakthrough for catalysts innovation, in this section, we focus on several challenges of Fe-zeolite catalysts when used for lean burn vehicles exhaust purification. 3.1 Difficulties in Fe-zeolite preparation process The preparation method is a critical factor that regulates the structures of active sites and ultimately determines catalyst performance. Also the distribution of Fe species is subject to preparation method and pretreatment. Many publications have adopted different methods for both post-synthesis treatment and isomorphous substitution zeolite with iron. Typically, Table 1 provides a summary of different preparation methods of Fe-zeolite for NH3-SCR. The crucial parameters about catalyst composition and the protocol/condition for Fe introduction or post-treatment are involved. Wet ion-exchange [63], incipient wetness impregnation [64], solid-state ion-exchange [65], chemical vapour deposition (sublimation) [11], steaming extraction of isomorphously substituted Fe-zeolite [66] and one-pot hydrothermal synthesis [23] are the well-known preparation methods of Fe-zeolite that lead to the formation of extraframework Fe sites. Wet ion-exchange, which is most commonly used, shows a limitation that it seems impossible to utilize full ion-exchange capacity of the zeolite. On this basis, chemical vapor deposition of volatile precursors FeCl3 onto zeolite acid sites was developed, achieving a high Fe/Al ratio = 1. On the other hand, the complex chemistry of iron ions in aqueous solutions leads to difficulties in wet ion-exchange. The details are as follows: 1) Care must be taken since FeII ions are easily oxidized to FeIII in aqueous solution [67]. So, ion exchange in ferrous salts solution is conducted in inert gases to avoid oxidation; 2) Bulky Fe-complexes with a large hydration shell will form during ion exchange. This arises difficulties for ions to overcome steric hindrance and then exchange/penetrate into zeolite pores; 3) FeIII ions tend to agglomerate, forming hydroxide precipitates that easily evolve into iron oxide/hydroxide clusters/aggregates. To settle the problem, low PH environment needs to be strictly controlled, or oxalate salt can be used as chelating ligand to inhibit aggregation; 4) Few soluble iron salts precursor are available, such as ferrous sulfate and ferrous chloride. The relatively poor solubility reduces the ion exchange rate. To avoid these problems, one-pot hydrothermal synthesis of Fe-zeolites is experimentally verified by several groups recently [23,68,69]. EDTA-FeIIINa (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid ferric sodium), TEPA-FeII (tetraethylenepentamine ferrous complex) and ironII salt were directly introduced into the zeolite gel precursor for hydrothermal synthesis. The one-pot synthesis provides an efficient and convenient method for the preparation of Fe-zeolite. Nevertheless, how to controllably prepare catalysts with maximum active species and better dispersity is problematic. Perhaps the design of single-atom catalyst will help us to achieve a breakthroughs in SCR by bringing out synergetic interaction between metal atoms and peripheral coordinated atoms. 3.2 The overconsumption and inhibition effect of NH3 on Fe-zeolite at low temperatures It is universally established that NO conversion at low temperatures is lower for Fe-zeolite catalysts in comparation to Cu-zeolite. Moreover, the standard NH3-SCR reaction rate at 240℃ on Fe/SSZ-13 with 1.2 wt.% Fe loading is 1.6∙10−7 mol NO g−1 s−1 in ref. [70], which is about three orders of magnitude lower than a Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst in ref. [71]. NH3 inhibition effect and NH3 overconsumption are two critical phenomena that cause the inferior low-temperature performance of Fe-zeolites. NH3 inhibition effect, as is observed for vanadia-based catalyst, is also observed in low-temperature SCR reaction on Fe-zeolite [72]. Conversely, Cu-zeolite has no such trouble even at temperatures as low as 150℃. For example, a study combining flow reactor experiments and kinetic modeling by Sjovall et al. investigated the ammonia inhibition on Cu-ZSM-5 at low temperature. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), when increasing the inlet NH3 concentration from 200−800 ppm in humid feed at 175℃, nearly no NH3 inhibition was observed at NH3/NO ≤ 1, resulting in an enhanced NO conversion [73]. NH3 inhibition is widely discussed in kinetic model study. It is distinct in Fig. 7(b) that the inhibition effect for Fe-ZSM-5 is more pronounced at low temperature (< 350℃), where the deNOx activity increasing is prevented by NH3 content in excess. Specifically, the NH3 inhibition effect appeared early at NH3/NOx ≥ 0.2 at 200℃ [74]. The extent of NH3 inhibition decreases with increasing temperature and ultimately disappears at 400℃. Indeed, there are two academic opinions to this point. One is that the inhibition is attributed to competitive adsorption of ammonia and NO on active Fe sites [75–77]. Based on this, the dependency on vacant sites was considered in the rate expression to involve the inhibition of high surface NH3 coverage [40]. Further, on behalf of the inhibiting effect, a redox site in kinetic model was derived to describe NH3 spillover from acidic sites to redox sites [78]. In Fig. 8 , Boubnov et al. [79] suggested the probable reason of NH3 inhibition over Fe-ZSM-5 by the strong affinity Fe sites of SCR intermediate to NH3. The competitive adsorption mechanism over H-ZSM-5 was also previously proposed by Stevenson et al. since the inhibition degree of reaction rate decreased with temperature increased [80]. Another possible explanation is based on a redox mechanism. Devadas et al. suggested that the inhibition effect was due to an easy reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+ below 300℃ in excess NH3, which decreased the active Fe3+ [50]. In addition to standard SCR reaction, the ammonia blocking appears in fast SCR reaction as well. Dedicated transient reactivity runs were performed by Grossale et al. [81]. It was evidenced that NH3 combined with surface nitrates to form ammonium nitrate at low temperatures. Thus further reduction of nitrate by NO was blocked because NH3 captured the key intermediate in an unreactive form. The deviations from the 1:1 stoichiometry of the standard SCR reaction (NH3 overconsumption) is common for Fe-zeolite catalysts. In order to ensure a sufficient NH3 dosing, a slightly excess of NH3 is usually feed to the simulated exhaust. Kinetic analysis with global Langmuir-Hinshelwood type rate equations by Bacher et al. indicated that the NO assisted NH3 oxidation must be introduced to describe the overconsumption behavior at low temperatures [82]. Hence, the rate was proportional to the NH3, O2 and NO concentrations. Correspondingly, experimental evidence of the mechanism behind NH3 overconsumption during SCR over Fe-zeolites was obtained by isotope labeling experiment [83]. At low temperatures, direct NH3 oxidation with only O2 did not occur. However, 14NH3 was oxidized to 14NO in the presence of 15NO, which was called the parasitic ammonia oxidation. The NH3 overconsumption decreases the NH3 concentration available for NO reduction, and thus inhibits the NO conversion to N2. 3.3 Hydrothermal deactivation To reduce NOx and PM simultaneously in diesel exhaust, the SCR system is installed in the adjacent unit of diesel particulate filters (DPF). The thermal regeneration of DPF causes the increase of exhaust temperatures with about 10 % H2O existing, contributing to the high temperature hydrothermal aging condition. Hydrothermal deactivation causes a persistent issue for the practical application of SCR catalysts. In regard to Fe-zeolite, the hydrothermal deactivation presents a disparate characteristic from Cu-zeolite. Typically, the activity after aging decreases in low temperatures range, while at higher temperatures the activity remains high [18,84]. It is assumed that a great part of catalytic sites are not employed at high temperatures because of the high reaction rate. And high-temperature deactivation is visible when it occurs in a quite severe extent. In addition, monomeric iron was supposed to be the dominant low-temperature active species, which was more susceptible to hydrothermal treatment [85]. These could be the reasons for relatively slight deactivation observed at higher temperatures. By means of mechanism investigation on hydrothermal deactivation, explanations in previous reports are summarized here. Deactivation occurs in three ways: 1) The deterioration of zeolite structure. For one thing, the loss of support area and zeolite channel/pore lead to destruction of textural properties [86]. For another, chemical properties of support are changed to some extent [87]. The Si-O-Al bonds are not as stable as the Si-O-Si bonds and are hydrolyzed by water [88]. Thus the remove of AlO4 tetrahedral happens with varying surface groups. Si-OH groups surrounding a void form to give a defect; 2) The loss of catalytic active Fe sites. The migration of iron ions out of ion exchange sites is prompted in the presence of water [89]. Then aggregation occurs after migration of ion-exchanged iron to form metal oxide clusters and particles with reduced NOx reduction activity [90]. Shwan et al. [84] observed the increase of Fe3+ concentration after a longstanding aging treatment by XPS. And the increased activity for NO oxidation and significant decrease of low-temperature NH3-SCR activity indicated the formation of large FeO3 particles. Meanwhile, the detached Al would interact with FeOx clusters to form FeAlOx phase, which inhibits the oxidation catalysis and redox cycling [91]; 3) The loss of catalytically related acid sites. It is seen in Fig. 9 that the ammonia storage capacity drastically decreases with increasing aging temperature and time. Brønsted acid sites are significantly decreased due to dealumination [92]. The DRIFTS spectra of NH3-saturated samples are helpful to detect the variation of Brønsted acid sites after aging, especially by OH stretching region [93]. Iwasaki et al. pointed out that the degree of dealumination depended on the zeolite nature (pore structure, Al content, crystallinity and crystal size) and Fe exchange degree [92]. In the development of durable Fe-zeolites, Fe-CHA, Fe-SSZ-39 and Fe-LTA are promising candidates in recent years. Martin et al. synthesized Fe-CHA by a one-pot method using N,N,N-trimethyladamantylammonium or tetraethylammonium as template, which not only showed excellent catalytic activity but also high hydrothermal stability, especially when sodium cations were selectively removed [94]. Likewise, they have prepared Fe-SSZ-39 with high hydrothermal stability by one-pot synthesis [95]. The success in synthesizing stable Fe-zeolite catalysts is tentatively attributed to the benefits of small pore zeolites. By Zr doping, aged Fe-SSZ-13 definitely remained high NO conversion in our unpublished work. Furthermore, high-silica Fe-LTA by Ryu et al. exhibited high NH3-SCR activity even after hydrothermal aging at 900 °C, as seen in Fig. 10 . The difference of intrazeolite locations and stability of iron ions and small iron oxide clusters in Fe-LTA from those in Fe-SSZ-13 are the reason for excellent hydrothermal stability [96]. Efforts to resist hydrothermal deactivation of Fe-zeolite are insufficient. Fundamentally, inhibition of dealumination and migration of active species may be effective way to develop stable automotive catalysts in the future. 3.4 Summary Compared to Cu-zeolite, the challenges of Fe-zeolite in the application of NH3-SCR reaction are concluded in this part, including the difficulties in Fe-zeolite preparation process, the overconsumption and inhibition effect of NH3 on Fe-zeolite at low temperatures and the poor hydrothermal stability. Focused on these challenges, the next chapter is devoted to review the solutions to optimize the catalytic performance of Fe-zeolite SCR catalysts in different aspects. 4 The solutions to optimize catalytic performance of Fe-zeolite SCR catalysts 4.1 The strategies to improve low-temperature activity NOx produced during cold start accounts for a great part of the total NOx emissions. It pushes forward the demand for prospective catalysts with enhanced low-temperature activity. A number of strategies are proposed from different aspects with regard to Fe-zeolite: 1) To expand the types of zeolite support that can be used for SCR reactions. Hitherto, zeolites with different framework structures and compositions have been used as supports for iron exchange. Recently, an innovative Fe-UZM-35 with Si/Al = 8.9 and Fe/Al = 0.35 was reported to show significantly higher activity at temperature below 573 K compared to other Fe-zeolite catalysts (beta, LTA, SSZ-13) [97]. This was considered to be the result of more low-temperature active isolated Fe3+ sites in Fe-UZM-35. But the large-pore nature may perform to the disadvantage of hydrothermal aging. Although its low temperature NO conversion above 250℃ basically reached the same level as the Cu-SSZ-13 in ref [98], its activity below 250℃ remained to be improved; 2) To adopt different post-synthesis treatment methods. Pretreatment is a significant parameter to regulate catalyst reactivity. In the research by Nedyalkova et al. [99], Fe-BEA pretreated in H2 at 650℃ for 5 h exhibited higher low-temperature activity than the untreated sample. The improvement was explained by the redispersion of iron, wherein the iron oxide clusters were decomposed into smaller units that strongly bonded to the zeolite matrix. Similarly, when the improved low-temperature activity is compared with the Cu-SSZ-13 in ref [98], there is a gap between the NOx conversion at 150−250℃; 3) To utilize the synergic effect of other metal/oxide component. Thus far, many studies have focused on improving low-temperatures catalytic activity by doping/modifying catalysts [100–102]. Mn-based catalyst, which is used as excellent low-temperature SCR catalysts for stationary sources, was introduced as a co-component of Fe to prepare Mn-Fe/ZSM5 with excellent low-temperature SCR activity and N2 selectivity [103]. In this case, the NO conversion over the Mn(20)–Fe(10)/ZSM5 at 200℃ reached up to 100 %, which was is even better than that of Cu-SSZ-13 in ref [98]. It was the well-dispersed MnO2 and the high surface acidity of Mn-Fe/ZSM5 that were to be responsible for the improved performance. Also in Fig. 11 , the synergic effect of Fe-SSZ-13 and FeMnTiZrOx is suggested [104], which resulted in almost equivalent activity to Cu-SSZ-13 in ref [98] in low-temperature range. Fe0.2Mn0.4TiZr0.03 activates gaseous NO + O2 to form nitrate/nitrite intermediates. It then migrates to surface NH4 + species adsorbed on Fe-CHA, releasing N2 at low temperatures. The strongly adsorbed NH3 on Fe-SSZ-13 prohibits the ammonia oxidation on Fe0.2Mn0.4TiZr0.03 to form N2O, simultaneously improving the high temperature activity; 4) To control the reaction conditions. In the previous discussion about the effect of NO2/NOx ratio, the fast SCR reaction is demonstrated to be an easy approach to drastically increase the NO reduction efficiency, particularly for Fe-zeolites. 4.2 The structural manipulations to improve activity and durability The rational design and regulation of catalyst structure is verified to be an effective method to impressively improve catalytic activity and durability [105]. As a result, a large number of studies have prepared Fe-zeolite catalysts with distinct morphology and spatial structure. Herein, some typical structural design ideas are listed to provide directions for future research. The basic structure regulation method is to change the morphology or size of catalyst (support or active species). On the one hand, Feng et al. prepared Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts following this idea, finding that support with cauliflower-like morphology was beneficial to the distribution of active isolated Fe3+ and catalytic ability [106]. On the other hand, Shi et al. prepared a Fe-ZSM-5/WM by ion-exchange method using the mixed solvent composed of 50 % deionized water and 50 % absolute methanol, which showed a wide active temperature window, good SO2 and H2O resistance, and good hydrothermal stability [107]. The shapes of the iron species on Fe-ZSM-5/WM were like little particles, different from the silk-like iron species prepared from 100 % absolute methanol or abundant Fe clusters prepared from 100 % deionized water. The overall improvement was a consequence of the improved dispersion of Fe clusters, appropriate ratio of Fe3+/Fe2+, increased oxidation properties, and sufficient surface-adsorbed oxygen species. Specially, the maintained low-temperature activity of aged Fe-ZSM-5/WM is remarkable, which outperforms the aged Fe-SSZ-13 reported in ref. [108]. More complicated, the design of hierarchical/core-shell structure catalysts has attracted much attention for their sophisticated properties and unique synergetic effect. A part of research is devoted to synthesize Fe-zeolite@nonmetal oxide catalyst, which is constituted with catalytic active Fe-zeolite core and protective nonmetal oxide shell. It was reported by Du et al. [109] that the hydrophobic silicalite-1 shell formed via two-step hydrothermal crystallization can protect Fe-ZSM-5 from impact of H2O, besides, the dispersive Fe species in silicalite-1 shell may catalyze reduction of NOx adsorbed on it. Analogously, a SiO2 shell layer on Fe-ZSM-5 was constructed by chemical liquid deposition to enhance the resistance to C3H6 poisoning [110]. Another part of research is committed to synthesize Fe-zeolite@metal oxide catalyst, where the metal oxide shell layer plays a role in catalytic pathway. Ceria is widely used as a promoter due to its excellent oxygen storage ability and high redox potential. Fe-ZSM-5@Ce/mesoporous-silica developed by Zhang et al. [111] was proposed to catalyze NH3-SCR through a sequential reaction strategy, thus facilitated the low/medial-temperature activity. The strong redox ability of Ce/mesoporous-silica shell promoted NO oxidation to NO2, contributing to the fast SCR reaction process over Fe-ZSM-5 core. Also by Chen et al. [112], Fe-ZSM-5@CeO2 catalyst fabricated via dopamine polymerization showed an elevated activity owing to a fast SCR environment (NO2 formation) created by the CeO2 oxidizing layer. The preparation route and reaction mechanism for Fe-ZSM-5@CeO2 is shown in Fig. 12 . Furthermore, high chemically stable and corrosion resistant TiO2 was used to prepared Fe/Beta@TiO2 core-shell catalyst [113]. The reduced acidity by TiO2 shell helped to exhibit an improved thermal stability and better C3H6/H2O resistance. Besides, different from fabricating core-shell structure, a novel iron encapsulated hollow beta zeolite was prepared through a desilication-recrystallization mechanism, and its good low-temperature activity came from the synergy between the Fe3+ species and Brønsted acid sites [114]. On the whole, the structure design of NH3-SCR catalysts has been extensively implemented. The beneficial effects by modifying mainly work in the following aspects: 1) By regulating the Fe species distribution to synthesize Fe-zeolite with specific properties, such as better catalytic performance; 2) By constructing protective layer outside the Fe-zeolite on condition that the reactant diffusion is not inhibited, thus to improve the resistance to poisons in SCR reaction, for instance, the advance in C3H6/H2O resistance; 3) By creating sequential reaction on active Fe-zeolite via facilitating a pre-step on nonzeolite component, which assists NO oxidation to NO2 and accelerates deNOx rate by the fast SCR reaction; 4) By exerting the synergetic effects and interfacial effects, which helps to enhance the SCR activity. 4.3 The combination of Fe- and Cu-based zeolite to expand the active temperature window Given the discrepancy of Fe- and Cu-zeolites in SCR application, it has been hypothesized that the combination of the two components potentially can offer a viable approach to expand the active temperature window. Many authors have devoted efforts to combined catalysts. Studies were focused on identifying the influence of build-up sequence [115], configuration [116], optimal catalyst loading [117] and thickness of the layer [31] etc. on activity [38], hydrothermal stability [118], N2O production [119] and resistance of poisons [120], respectively. Changeable combinations are advised in relevant literature. The composite catalysts can be divided into two major categories in terms of the composition of starting materials. The first class is the combination of the respective Cu- or Fe- single component zeolite catalyst. For example, the combined catalysts that has been reported contain Fe-ZSM-5+Cu-CHA, Fe-ZSM5+Cu-ZSM5, Cu-SAPO-34+Fe-MOR and so on. There are several approaches to combine different monometallic-zeolite catalysts: 1) A single brick made up of a dual layer configuration. In the case, catalyst is prepared by depositing the Fe and Cu washcoat slurries sequentially over monolith. It involves the question of coating sequence and thickness of each layer. Metkar et al. fixed the total washcoat mass and monolith length of monolith catalysts and changed the mass ratio and order of each layer between the Cu-ZSM-5 and Fe-ZSM-5, finding that catalyst with 1:2 ratio of Fe-ZSM-5 top layer:Cu-ZSM-5 bottom layer gave the highest NOx conversion [121]. The working principle is shown in Fig. 13 . At low temperatures, the top Fe layer performs as a inactive diffusion barrier and the bottom Cu layer works to achieve NOx conversion, while at high temperatures, NOx reduction occurs at the thin top layer of Fe-zeolite; 2) A sequential brick configuration with the series arrangement of Fe and Cu-bricks. Studies on position arrangement of bricks and the optimal catalyst loadings are conducted. By maintaining the same residence time and total washcoat thickness, it was provided by Shakya et al. that the adverse effect of diffusional resistance in the dual-brick configuration was not as detrimental as dual-layer catalyst and the computed optimal Fe-SCR content for the dual brick configuration was ca. 20 % [116]. In addition, a sequential arrangement of short Fe-ZSM-5 brick followed by longer Cu-CHA brick was confirmed to be of practical interest [31]; 3) Mixed washcoat of monolithic catalyst. The washcoat comprises a mixture of different fractions of Fe- and Cu-zeolites in the slurry; 4) The mechanical mixing method. In ref. [122], the mechanical mixture (50:50) of Cu-SAPO-34 and Fe-Mordenite was compared with individual zeolite, showing inferior activity at NH3/NOx = 1 with ca. 30 % high-temperature overconsumption of ammonia. However, an enhancement of SCR activity in the whole temperature range was achieved at NH3/NOx = 1.3. The second class is the synthesis of Cu-Fe co-existing bimetallic zeolite catalyst. Among the bimetallic zeolite catalyst, complementary advantage and bimetallic effect are highlighted [123]. The common methods for (Fe + Cu)-zeolites preparation are as listed below: 1) Co-ion exchange or co-impregnation of iron salt and copper salt; 2) Sequential ion exchange/immersion; 3) Solid-state ion-exchange method, which can be facilitated by the presence of NH3 and NO [124]. Commonly, two metal nitrate and H-zeolite are mixed and heated at high temperature, and the solid mixture can be replaced by physical mixing of metal oxide and metal-exchange zeolite (such as CuO + Fe-beta [125]); 4) Monometallic zeolites are synthesized by one-pot method and then the second metal is introduced by ion exchange or wet impregnation. Whatever the method, the temperature window can be controlled by changing the fraction of copper and iron content. Some potential advantages of the combined catalyst are commented here. First, it shows high NOx removal efficiency over a wider temperature window. Especially for the Fe-only zeolites with unsatisfying low-temperature activity, the utilization of combined catalyst can improve activity without the increase of NO2 concentration in the feed. This indirectly reduces the consumption of Pt in the upstream DOC system, which converts NO to NO2. Besides the cost efficiency due to less precious metal consumption, the potential contamination threat of SCR catalyst by Pt travelling from DOC is also reduced. Second, because of the high-temperature advantage of Fe-zeolite, the high-temperature ammonia oxidation over Cu-zeolite is evitable. Thus, the need for high NH3/NO ratio due to ammonia oxidation side reactions over Cu-zeolite is avoid, which in turn causes reduced ammonia/urea consumption. Third, both Fe- and Cu-zeolites are also effective to oxidize NH3 to N2 [126,127], and the combined catalyst can use as a NH3-slip catalyst (to prevent NH3 emissions by oxidation). Fourth, a clear synergetic effect can be observed regarding N2O formation. The N2O formed on Cu sites is transferred to Fe sites nearby, subsequently decomposed on Fe sites. Fifth, the composite catalyst not only serves as a method to improve reactivity, but also can realize fine-tune. Conclusively, the advantages of Fe/Cu composite catalysts can be understood from different perspectives, containing complementarity, dispersity, redox behavior, bimetallic/synergetic effect, diffusion effect, nanocomposite, and number of active sites. However, a adverse effect was observed by Girard et al. that the combined SCR catalyst of Fe-zeolite in front of Cu-zeolite gave a higher NH3 slip amount below 300℃ than Cu-only system [128]. Also for a comparison of individual Cu- or Fe-zeolite catalyst in ref. [129], Fe-SCR showed higher NH3 slip relative to Cu-SCR under different ammonia to NOx ratio. This must be considered for on-road vehicles, since NH3 slip will go through a diesel particulate filter in the downstream, where oxidation occurs to form NOx. Further, an NH3 oxidation catalyst is needed to selectively oxidize the unreacted NH3 from SCR units into N2 and H2O, which is called the NH3-SCO reaction [130]. 5 The reaction mechanisms of NH3-SCR over Fe-zeolites On the mechanism of NH3-SCR reaction, it is a consensus that the coexistence of acid circle and redox circle is requisite for both vanadium and zeolite catalysts. Nevertheless, investigations have derived various discussions on identification of reactive acid sites and active metal sites and on activation pathway of reactive molecules, causing the uncertainty in current understanding on reaction intermediate. Concerning catalytic cycle of Cu-zeolite, abundant information is experimentally and theoretically captured about intermediate structure, transformations of Cu active species and role of acid sites. In a typical manner in Fig. 14 , Janssens et al. [131] first described the standard SCR reaction as a coupling of the NO activation by O2 with the fast SCR reaction in a complete cycle that enabled the correct stoichiometry while allowing adsorption and desorption of stable molecules only. The catalytic cycle was closed by an oxidation of the catalyst by NO + O2 and a reduction by NO + NH3, with the oxidation of NO by O2 as the rate determining step. These intermediates involved in the scheme are also generally detected for Fe-zeolite, i.e., nitrite, nitrate and nitroamide. Atomic-level understanding of in-situ Cu sites transformations, such as interaction with NH3 and H2O, is clearly obtained. Corresponding, the formation, migration and reaction of mobile [Cu(NH3)2]+ complexes is suggested to be significant [132,133], and in situ dynamic generation of multinuclear complexes as active sites in O2 activation was advised by Paolucci et al. [134]. However, owning to the complexity of Fe active sites, atomic-level exploration of Fe species evolution under SCR is blurry. Isolated Fe2+, isolated Fe3+, dimeric iron species, oligomeric species and Fe2O3 particles coexist, together with different nuclearity and charges over FexOy, which leads to disturbances in identifying activity of different sites. Brandenberger et al. [135] revealed that monomeric iron acted on the activity below 300 °C, and dimeric iron was the main active species at higher temperature. In our work, the nature of Fe species is regulated by calcination temperature and the identification of active sites is in line with the standpoint [136]. Different proposition was put forwarded by Høj et al. [137], indicating that monomeric iron was the actual active sites. Table 2 gives a summary of the characterizations of Fe species, including 57Fe Mossbauer, IR spectrum of NOx absorption, H2-TPR, EPR and UV–vis. The characteristic peaks/signals are presented and the identification of corresponding adsorbed/Fe species is concluded. Beside, the changes of the Fe active sites during SCR reaction is also of interest. The fractions of Fe2+ and Fe3+ were quantified by the combination of Mossbauer and X-ray absorption spectroscopy in ref. [138], the temperature-dependent species distribution during reaction indicated that the ion exchanged Fe2+/Fe3+ were reversibly oxidized and reduced. Reaction 8 is suggested to be the main step for the reduction of isolated Fe3+ [139]. And multinuclear Fe centers proceed the redox by a Mars–van Krevelen mechanism via the step of NO oxidization to NO2, as shown in reaction 9 [70]. Moreover, a dynamic redox feature of Fe species was also found by Kim et al. that Fe oxide clusters in situ formed at 723 K (reaction 10) could be dissociated to isolated Fe3+ in SCR condition at 423 K [140]. In the case, the redox cycle is proposed to exist via NH3 as reducing agent and O2 as oxidizing agent. Nevertheless, a DFT study by Li et al. suggest that the reduced [FeIIOH]+ model site can only be reoxidized by NO2 with the assistance of NH3 rather than by O2 or O2/NO mixtures [141]. Thus, the reoxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ is still problematic and it is believed to be a slow step in SCR [142]. (8) FeIII−OH + NO ⇌ FeII + HONO (9) [−FeIII−O − FeIII−] + NO → [−FeII−□−FeII−] + NO2 (ads) (10) 2Fe3+(OH)2 → [HO − FeIII−O − FeIII−OH] + H2O → [FeII−O − FeII] + H2O + 1 2 O2 According to literatures, SCR reaction mechanism over Fe-zeolite can be considered from two aspects: 1) On the activation of NH3. It is believed that NH3 is protonated to NH4 + on Brönsted acid center [47] or activated via an NH bond cleavage on Lewis acid center to form amide species [143]. These are the possible rate-limiting step for Eley-Rideal type mechanism. In the publication of Klukowski et al. [144], a dual site mechanism in Fig. 15 showed that the adsorption and reaction of NO and NH3 occurred on neighboring Fe3+ sites, where NH3 underwent adsorption/desorption cycles on the substrate before spilling-over from the zeolitic and reacting on the Fe3+ sites. It was proposed that NHx directly coordinated on Fe sites is the real intermediate with a tendency towards fast consumption [79]. Further, the variation of NH3-adsorbed species on Fe sites is shown in Fig. 16 . The initial Fe(ZO)(OH)2 species reacts with NH3 to form Fe(ZO)(OH)(NH2), which may combine with another NH3 to prohibit its reaction with NO or directly react with NO to form Fe(ZO)(OH)(NH2)(NO) [145]. The later will transform into Fe(ZO)(ONOH)(NH2) that is easy to decompose into N2 and H2O, along with the formation of Fe2+(ZO)(OH). It is worth noting that the Fe2+(ZO)(OH) may coordinate with two molecules of ammonia to stabilize Fe2+, thus inhibiting its reoxidation to Fe3+. 2) On the activation of NOx. Rather than free NO2, NO2-adsorbed transitional species are widely accepted to form preferentially, which further dimerize and disproportionate to nitrate/nitrite (acid/salt form) [49,139]. Afterwards, -NH4NO3, -NH4NO2 or -NH2NO are formed [146]. Stable -NH4NO3 is further reduced by NO to -NH4NO2, along with the release of NO2. Conversely, unstable -NH4NO2 and -NH2NO are directly decomposed to N2 and H2O [147]. Ruggeri et al. [148] mixed Fe-ZSM-5 with BaO/Al2O3 as a NOx trap to capture and stabilize reactive NOx intermediates formed on Fe-ZSM-5, of which the results supported the oxidative activation of NO at low temperatures to form nitrite adspecies. As shown in Fig. 17 , the features at 1640 and 1384 cm−1 assigned to nitrates species are evident for Fe-ZSM-5 individual sample but absent for the Fe-ZSM-5 component from the mechanical mixture. Instead, the bands of nitrite/nitrate adspecies, such as 1110, 1220, 1350 and 1410 cm−1, are observed on BaO/Al2O3 component from the mechanical mixture, but this is not the case for BaO/ Al2O3 individual sample. These indicated that nitrites intermediate was trapped and stored on BaO in a stable form. In regard to fast SCR chemistry in Fig. 18 , it is presented that the reduction of nitrates by NO is the rate-limiting step. However, much remains to be done in microcosmic aspect, such as how the solvation effect of iron species contributes in the reaction, how the configuration of active sites changes, whether dynamic migration will happen, and how to clarify the dynamic cycle. 6 Conclusions and perspectives With the popularity of zeolite catalysts in deNOx process of mobile source exhaust, extraordinary successes have been achieved in application of Fe and Cu modifying zeolite. A more sophisticated SCR system catalyzed by Cu-zeolite has been shown in previous studies. However, many details of Fe-zeolite system are still unknown, remaining to be clarified. In this review, the Fe-zeolite catalysts for NH3-SCR of NOx are evaluated based on the relative advantages and disadvantages in comparison to Cu-zeolite catalysts. These figure out the valuable functions of Fe-zeolite that are to be emphasized and the shortcomings that are to be improved. Aiming at the realistic challenges of Fe-zeolite catalysts, the hidden reasons behind low-temperature NH3 overconsumption and NH3 inhibition effect are probed and multiple strategies are proposed for improving low-temperature activity and catalytic durability (including hydrocarbon poisoning, hydrothermal and chemical deactivation). The advances in the SCR reaction mechanisms over Fe-zeolite are concluded as well. Herein, the summaries about the catalytic characteristics and issues for future investigations of Fe-zeolite are given below: 1) The outstanding performance of high-temperature NOx conversion, the low selectivity of N2O and the higher resistance to sulfur poisoning over Fe-zeolite can all be effective supplement for commercially used Cu-zeolite catalysts. 2) Because of the sensitivity of Fe-zeolite catalysts to inevitable NO2 in exhaust, its application in vehicle is greatly affected by the actual working conditions and may not provide stable and efficient low-temperature activity. But to a certain degree, once precise NO2 regulation is achieved, it provides a feasible way for Fe-zeolite to facilitate low-temperature activity by fast SCR reaction. 3) The catalytic performance of Fe-zeolite depends closely on active species structure and distribution. Therefore, more attention should be paid to explore practicable topological zeolite with special porous structure/morphology and to design/modify structure by post-treatment with increased catalytic performance. 4) Deactivation, especially for hydrothermal deactivation, has been a driving force for catalyst innovation. Fe-zeolite catalysts also face with this challenging task. Strategies to stabilize Fe species from aggregation and to protect zeolite from destruction are needed. 5) So far, some aspects have not been considered sufficiently for the multiple impacts of SO2, H2O, inorganic poisons and other impurities on Fe-zeolite when these exist together. A comprehensive experimental verification is of significance to develop robust Fe-zeolite catalysts resistant to multiple poisoning. 6) The microscopic understanding of the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism over Fe-zeolite catalysts calls for more insight into surface chemical process. More thorough ex situ, in situ and operando spectroscopic studies, steady-state and transient kinetic investigations, time-resolved monitoring techniques as well as theoretical calculation and simulation are required to further identify the active intermediates and sites, dynamic variation of Fe species, structure-activity relationships and reaction pathway. Through this review, we expect to pave a way for future design and development of Fe-zeolite SCR catalysts on the basis of a basic understanding of its characteristics. coredata.dc:description: Selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 over zeolite catalysts is recognized as the most practical technology used in mobile exhaust gases to transform NOx into N2. Despite a comprehensive structural-activity insight into Cu-zeolite SCR catalyst, Fe-zeolite, which is also popular in the automotive catalysis community, is necessary to be thoroughly investigated on micro-mechanism. This review summarizes the highlights and challenges in the application of Fe-zeolite, and simultaneously analyzes the reasons of some peculiar properties, such as the NH3 inhibition effect at low temperatures, the low N2O production and the sensitivity to NO2/NOx ratio in the feed. In addition, some feasible strategies are classified and summarized subsequently to provide suggestions for the improvement of low-temperature activity, the enhancement of resistance to hydrothermal aging and sulfur poisoning, the construction of controlled structure and the combination of Fe- and Cu- zeolites. Finally, the reaction mechanisms of NH3-SCR over Fe-zeolites are concluded. After establishing a comprehensive overview of Fe-zeolite SCR catalysts, some directions that remain to be thoroughly explored on Fe-zeolite are put forward to assist the future catalyst design and investigation of NH3-SCR.
coredata.dc:title: The opportunities and challenges of iron-zeolite as NH3-SCR catalyst in purification of vehicle exhaust
